{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient's symptoms of early satiety, nonbilious vomiting of undigested food, and weight gain suggest gastric outlet obstruction. The succussion splash (splashing sound heard on auscultation of the upper abdomen while rocking the patient back and forth) is a physical examination finding consistent with this diagnosis. Gastric outlet obstruction can be caused by a variety of conditions, including peptic ulcer disease, gastric polyps, and malignancy. Given the patient's history of smoking, alcohol use, and family history of gastrointestinal cancer, as well as the presence of occult blood in the stool, a neoplastic growth is the most likely cause of his symptoms.", "answer_choice": "C"}
